Subject: Re: [junit] Re: writing a test case for a function which returns void

From: Johannes Link <john.link@...>

> 
> Hi,
> I am novice in Junit. So bear with me. Does it make sense to write a test
> case for a function which returns
> void. For example for a function like
> 
>    public void Func( int x, int y){
>   
> 
>   }

A function which returns void is either useless or produces some side
effect(s) (in that case I wouldn't call it a "function" though). Testing for the
side effects can make sense if those effects can be observed from the outside
easily enough.
E.g. if you have a method which changes the state of an object, you can test
that the object's state has changed if the object provides a getter for that
piece of state. Sometimes a side effect means that from now on the object's
future behaviour will be different. In that case, test the future behaviour.

In general, the effect of a method (or function) can be manifold. Thinking
is required to assert that the expected effect has taken place - and only
that.

Hope that helps,
Johannes
subject: Re: [junit] Re: writing a test case for a function which returns void
